Slides.caption: Our farm activities extend not only to catering for our healthy animals. But we also advise and help other local farmers on zero grazing and other productive farming practices.

Slides.slideTitle: Besides dairy  we do other farming projects
Slides.caption: With most emphasis on Dairy, We also carry out fish farming, plantation and more which in return help us for food security, income and feeding our animals

About.paragraph: Buyanga dairy farm's Inspiration grew when our Director Mr. Samuel kalungi visited Nyeri, kenya Meeting a farmer who says he started with 2 cows but currently grew a population of upto 230 cows. We've been in existence from 2020 to date and from 2 cows to 17 cows. And we're working painstakingly not only on dairy farming but in other fields like aqua culture, cultivation and much more.
About.vision: Atleast in the middle or by the end of the decade we'll have grown our farm from 17 to a warping 200 animals. And have managed to help a number of local farmers so the chain of development is kept steady
About.mission: Our ambition is to fight poverty through building and growing productive farming systems for ourselves and the local farmers in our area. We guide them on how to breed healthy animals.

Gallery.title: Banana plantation
Gallery.description: we have a full hectare of bananas

Gallery.title: Canning our milk
Gallery.description: canning our milk in the morning

Services.name: Dairy farming and food security
Services.text: We keep our animals(cows) purposely to generate income and for diary products like beef, milk, butter, cheese etc! And from 2 cows we've managed to keep around 15 more animals

Services.name: Advisory and inspiration
Services.text: We push knowledge down to the local farmers nearby on effective farming practices through organizing and attending seminars, Organizing the farmers into groups to grow together

Services.name: Guiding local farmers on breeds
Services.text: With close attention offered through guiding them, to we also help our local farmers deeply technical practices like articifial insermination, breeding their animals, keeping records(how many liters of milk the cows produce and more)

Services.name: Finding market for farmer's products
Services.text: Since it's all about income. We've helped farmers on finding better market for their produce. Where they can sell their milk

Services.name: Small scale gardens
Services.text: On the side, we also grow crops, we practice and encourage modern practices like small scale vertical gardens of skuma wiki, we have a large banana plantations and make use of the cow dung from the animals to as pesticides and fertilizers

Services.name: Aquaculture
Services.text: we have ponds of fish and aim to encourage farmers on aqua culture too

Blog.title: From Kenya to Bangladesh: 5 Ways Heifer Builds Strong Market Systems
Blog.article: The road to resilient food systems is not without its obstacles. A changing climate often complicates harvests. Natural disasters flood fields and damage yields. And, sometimes, a novel pathogen triggers a once-in-a-century pandemic, battering supply chains and forcing agricultural workers to stay home. Heifer understands working toward a world free of poverty and hunger means planning now for an unpredictable future. For lasting change, we’re thinking big by working local, improving the collective power of smallholder farmers through technical training and business support, and by developing sturdy market systems at the community level. This requires investing — in local farmers and their communities, the infrastructure they use and the systems in place that enable the most vulnerable to earn a Sustainable Living Income, generating wealth to lift themselves out of poverty. And the stakes are high: Efficient market systems and fair prices give farmers the purchasing power to keep nutritious food on the table and roofs above their heads. Investing in infrastructure across our projects in Asia, Africa and the Americas paves the way forward for farmers’ success.

Blog.title: How Heifer Supports Farmers Through Education
Blog.article: On this International Day of Education we recognize the important role that education plays in improving the lives and livelihoods of farmers around the world. Heifer has a long history of supporting farmers as they join cooperatives to share knowledge, pool resources, and access financing to invest and grow their farms and businesses. Through our Community Mobilization model Heifer has created a framework for building the skills of individuals and communities as they work together to achieve their goals. Supporting the world’s poorest households to earn a Sustainable Living Income requires attention to the skills and information that are most needed to begin their journey. For instance, essential literacy skills empower women in remote rural villages, while record keeping and business plan training supports first-time farmers as they start their businesses. Throughout the training process, individuals and self-help groups are active agents in their own development, implementing what they have learned in their lives as parents and family members, entrepreneurs and cooperative leaders as well as other roles and opportunities opened through training from Heifer. These efforts are aimed at accelerating progress towards United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 4, which seeks to improve access to education for all.
